App description:
Layers of Fear VR is a psychedelic horror game that pulls you into the depths of insanity. Now its constantly changing Victorian mansion can be explored without limits thanks to the all-in-one Virtual Reality experience of Oculus Quest.
Delve deep into the mind of an insane painter and discover the secret of his madness. Uncover the visions, fears and horrors that entwine the painter and finish the masterpiece he has strived so long to create.
Redesigned with Quest in mind for greater interactivity and immersion, Layers of Fear VR is a first-person horror game built on a rich, dark story. Explore an environment overflowing with macabre artwork and unravel secrets through twisted puzzles. Take control of a painter seeking to create his magnum opus before losing his mind in the process.
The psychological horror of Layers of Fear will leave you questioning your own eyes and mind. Dare you help paint a true Masterpiece of Fear? Put on your Quest and discover what awaits

powney1991Jul 9 at 3:15 PM
Layers of fear! And they aint kidding!

Ok wow... as someone whos tried a lot of horror experiences and games in VR such as dreadhalls, affected the manor, the exorcist and what not I went into layers of fear tonight expecting another typical horror experience but nothing too exceptional... boy could I EVER have been more wrong!!!  Im just going to come out and say it this horror game/experience whatever you want to call it is UNBELIEVABLE!!! And a straight up psychological head wreck!!! From creepy sounds to crying, to slamming doors, to seeing dark figures walking around, dolls, darkness, hallucinations, things falling, going around in circles and feeling like youre going mad, my god this thing throws THE LOT at you!

The thing that separates it for me though from so many other horror experiences and games and what makes it stand out is the fact that when theres a horror scene theres multiple things happening around you! Its very easy in a horror game sometimes to miss something if you look the wrong way or in the wrong place but this actually registers where youre looking and will execute a scene based on that! Its clever and creepy as heck!! Theres parts for example where you might go down a corridor and reach a door. You then turn around and the scene may change then turn around again and its changed again which really makes your hairs stand on end and gets the blood pumping as youre expecting a scary scene to follow! Its crazy good and a real head wreck!

And it isnt short! The game is LONG and there comes a point where sometimes it gets so scary and intensely psychological a part of you just wants it to be over but another part is telling you to plod on and keep going! I did about 5 chapters in one play though and Im absolutely exhausted from the horror and psychological factors behind the game!

It really gives you a sense and interpretation of why this is all happening too and sucking you into the story behind it! I cant recommend it enough to anyone who is interested and for me I now think this is the best horror experience on the quest money can buy! I really believe its that good! Just prepare yourself when you go in! Its not for the faint hearted!

Eerie, mind twisting but glitchy

I am on chapter 4. I have played about 1.5 hours. The game starts out pretty calm with an eerie ambiance. As you gather pieces to the picture you are completing the levels of insanity increase. You feel like you are in the twisted mind of a madman. The story is grim and the visuals are good for a Quest port. There is a constant building of tension. You will often look one direction and then turn and look back to find that everything has changed.

It is not the heart pounding hide or run away feeling of Dread Halls. It is a great psychological mind game. You almost start feeling like you are the one going insane. I recommend playing with headphones.

The glitches: doors will often get stuck or not be able to grab handles and/or objects easily. Clipping is pretty bad in many areas and you end up not being able to move or the visuals jump around when trying to move. Object interaction isnt the smoothest.

I would also turn off subtitles as it helps with the immersion when you pick up items to be read. If you need to read them more easily you can press your trigger and the subtitles for the object appear in type. Press trigger again and they are gone. Otherwise you can hold notes closer to your face and try to read the cursive handwriting and notes (better immersive feeling)

I also turned off the tunnel vision as it breaks immersion for me. I dont usually get VR sickness so was fine.

5 stars if they fix the screen stuttering, getting stuck and glitchy object interaction that break immersion.

Layers of Terror more like

My first foray into horror games for my Quest was Affected: The Manor, which I thought Layers of Fear was going to be like.
Boy was I wrong.
Where Affected focuses on quick playthroughs and intense jump scares, Layers slowly throws terrifying slow burn moments at you over a much longer period of time, meaning that when the scare drops you're already on a knife edge, making it even scarier and more impactful.
There's also a deep backstory that unravels the further in you go, and the hairs on the back of my neck were on end pretty much the whole time I was reading the mysterious notes, letters and newspaper articles that reveal the lore.
I played a solid two hours in one go and I'm only at the third chapter. The game feels tremendously polished, there's a LOT going on here.
